headline.main: Topics ;   More Education, Less Science ;   AphrodisiacsNonprescription nostrums cannot correct either a lack of hair or a lack of ardor, says the Food and Drug Administration, responding to Congressional interest in over-the- counter drugs. The findings are not, in any scientific sense, surprising. Claims of miraculous cures for baldness probably date back as far as baldness. And aphrodisiacs, like the legendary Spanish fly, probably have never worked any place outside the imaginations of fevered schoolboys. The F.D.A. report is unsettling nonetheless, because of its lack of science. The agency implies that, apart from a still-experimental drug made from male hormones, there are no aphrodisiacs at all, not liquor and not even perfume. It sounds as though the F.D.A. is getting too caught up in the rigor of its own research.

key_1.snippet: THE RETURN OF THE BROWN PELICAN     Photographs by Dan Guravich.  Text by Joseph E. Brown.  Foreword by Roger Tory Peterson.  Illustrated. 118 pp....
key_1.lead_paragraph: THE RETURN OF THE BROWN PELICAN Photographs by Dan Guravich. Text by Joseph E. Brown. Foreword by Roger Tory Peterson. Illustrated. 118 pp.

headline.main: ANIMALS

byline.original: By Martin LevineBy  MARTIN  LEVINE more than his belican'' - he worries that the 73-year- old limerick may lead us to underestimate the bird's gastric capacity. (Fortunately, the pelican's habit of turning larger prey around inside its pouch to counter spiny fins is a documented wonder.)   Dan Guravich's color photographs constitute the book's main - and top-billed - attraction. More than 100 plates capture the blue of summer plumage, the gold and pink eyes of the breeding season, the condorlike flight. Five-week-old chicks look unpromisingly like plucked chickens topped by oversized brown vulture heads. An unsparing final series of photographs shows brown pelicans killed or mutilated by discarded fishhooks and nonbiodegradable nylon fishing line.  THE MARSH LIONS    The Story of an African Pride.  By Brian Jackman.  Illustrated by Jonathan Scott.  224 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $19.95; $24.95 after Dec. 31.     The watered grasslands of Kenya's Maasai Mara Game Reserve - in effect, the northern tip of Tanzania's Serengeti National Park - support giraffes, zebras, gazelles, wildebeest, elephants, black rhinos, water buffaloes and leopards. Above all, Mara is home to Africa's largest and finest population of lions.   Two British naturalists, Brian Jackman and Jonathan Scott, spent several years following a single pride with glances at the savanna's other wildlife. But for all its heaving, Mr. Jackman's prose never breaks free of cliche, though it concentrates tough-mindedly    Not to be confused with Jean- Claude Suar es' previous ''Illustrated Cat,'' ''Photographed Cat,'' ''Literary Cat,'' ''Preppy Cat,'' ''Great Cats'' or ''Cat Scrapbook,'' ''The Indispensable Cat'' pays another elegant tribute to what Anatole France called the only animal to have domesticated man.   There's not much natural history here, even if Mr. Suar es reminds us that cats have been part of human society for only half as long as dogs (5,000 versus 10,000 years). This is, however, the place to learn about such topics as cats in movies. Mack Sennett claimed to find the pioneer, a gate-crashing kitten named Pepper, ''as disarming as the lovely Lillian Gish.'' The poetry and prose included hew to traditional lines.   Among the artists, Edward Lear sketches himself as a fat stork stalked by his beloved, stump-tailed Foss; within his narrow range, George Herriman differentiates between lovesick Krazy and adored Mehitabel; and Fernando Botero paints a fat cat. One misses only an example of the schizophrenic English illustrator Louis Wain's electric-haired apparitions.  DOGS    By Rien Poortvliet.  Illustrated. Unpaged.  New York: Harry N. Abrams. $25.     ''Dogs'' proves a pleasant surprise after Rien Poortvliet's whimsical ''Gnomes'' and its sequels. Mr. Poortvliet sentimentalizes observable creatures too, but their postures and gazes are authentic. And even readers who deplore his aspirations to be a soft-focus Norman Rockwell (as in the many breed portraits in oil on textured canvas) should enjoy the fluent cartoons and earthy annotations of his sketchbook pages.   The current Poortvliet dogs - a pointer, a dachshund and two Jack Russell terriers - merit early and individual introductions. But the book's best story involves a runaway boxer, a windmill and a psychic. ''Cross my heart, not one word of it has been made up,'' the author assures us, but it reads like a collaboration between Alfred Hitchcock and Albert Payson Terhune.  DINOSAURS    An Illustrated History.  By Edwin H. Colbert.  224 pp. Maplewood, N.J.: A Dembner Book/Hammond.  $30.     The dean of American vertebrate paleontologists supplies a plodding text for illustrations that range from the pseudo-Bewickian to the proto-science-fictional. Readers willing to do some of the synthesis themselves should borrow their children's copies of ''The Illustrated Dinosaur Dictionary'' by Helen Roney Sattler (Lothrop, Lee & Shepard, $17.50) and ''A Field Guide to Dinosaurs'' by the Diagram Group (Avon, paper, $8.95), recommended last month in these pages.  WEIRD & WONDERFUL WILDLIFE    By Michael Marten, John May and Rosemary Taylor.  Illustrated. 224 pp.  San Francisco: Chronicle Books. Cloth, $27.50.  Paper, $14.95.     ''Weird & Wonderful Wildlife'' takes a loosely systematic look at some of nature's more striking evolutionary adaptations. While Michael Marten and his colleagues provide no separate text to speak of, their captions are long, specific and apparently accurate. One learns that the tentacles of a jellyfish called the arctic lion's mane can cover an area more than 500 yards square, that the platypus is one of the few poisonous mammals, that the 2-foot-long tongue of the giant anteater is worked by a muscle anchored to its breastbone.   The dramatic full-page color photographs range from the melancholy ruthlessness of the Philippine eagle (known as the monkey-eating eagle until President Ferdinand Marcos decreed a more dignified appellation) to the virtuosic sexual acrobatics of the great slug. Notwithstanding its carny- barker title, this is the season's best illustrated animal book.  THE GRAND DESIGN    Form and Colour in Animals.  By Sally Foy and Oxford Scientific Films.  Foreword by Gerald Durrell.  Illustrated. 238 pp.  Englewood Cliffs, N.J.: Prentice-Hall. $24.95.     Why are some animals cylinders, others disks and still others logarithmic helixes?  ''The Grand Design'' marries textbook prose, not without its ration of curiosities - an eagle's bones account for only 7 percent of its weight, half as much as its feathers; the male silk moth is physically unable to eat - to largish, surprisingly effective blowups from Oxford Scientific Films. The pictures lose surprisingly little in being abstracted from the group's action sequences for public television's ''Life on Earth'' and other series.  WALKER'S MAMMALS OF THE WORLD    Fourth Edition.  By Ronald M. Nowak and John L. Paradiso.  Illustrated. 1,362 pp. In two volumes. Baltimore: The Johns Hopkins University Press. $65.     A classic is worthily revised. Ernest P. Walker (1891-1969), long the assistant director of the National Zoological Park in Washington, not only edited the first, 1964 edition of ''Mammals of the World'' but dedicated himself to obtaining clear black- and-white photographs of every new exhibit at the zoo. Now, after a 90 percent revision of the generic descriptions - the write-ups of what a layman might call ''different animals'' - we have a much expanded fourth edition. It is a model of reference-book making, with page numbers running consecutively through the two volumes and an index to the complete work in each one. Only the condensed table of habitats and the mutually contradictory endangerment classifications pose a bar to easy use. . The book's avocational (or obsessional) origins remain agreeably apparent in some of the photographs' pasted-on, typewritten labels.   ''Walker's Mammals of the World'' is comparable only to the more elaborate, expensive and anecdotal Grzimek's Animal Life Encyclopedia (McGraw-Hill, 13 volumes). It provides up-to-date documentation for the professional and comments on the unique and superlative for the amateur. Of what animal can it be said that ''No other species has ever been as destructive to the habitat on which it depends for survival''? It makes a surprise appearance right after Gorilla gorilla in the ''Primates'' section

key_2.snippet: David Macdonald may take pride in his discoveries of the social behavior of foxes, but if his interpretations were accurately reported by Lois Wingerson, (Science Times, July 28), they reveal stereotypical male biases and two blatant contradiction...
key_2.lead_paragraph: David Macdonald may take pride in his discoveries of the social behavior of foxes, but if his interpretations were accurately reported by Lois Wingerson, (Science Times, July 28), they reveal stereotypical male biases and two blatant contradictions. A careful reading of the factual evidence reported in the article can support a quite different anthropomorphic rendering of the ''surprising'' group life of foxes. At one point, the article states that in a group consisting of a breeding female, a ''dominant male,'' and non-breeding females, it is these females that provide food, and groom and protect the cubs. Later on, the article states that where the food supply is abundant, ''a dominant male can afford to support several 'servant' vixens as well as his mate.''

key_2.lead_paragraph: Sexual competition among flowers is usually more subtle, but scientists studying neotropical orchids from the genus Catasetum have found the male orchids using an aggressive tactic to beat out their male rivals in the pollination of females. Plants in this genus are either male or female, and the flowers of each sex differ considerably in their structure and appearance.

key_6.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Natalie Angier's conversation with Virginia Valian, a professor of psychology and linguistics at Hunter College (Science Times, Aug. 25), offers a thoughtful and provocative analysis of the continuing disparity between the advancement of men and women in academia. However, Dr. Valian's characterization of the willingness of male researchers to publish hypotheses with meager supporting data as ''risk-taking'' misnames what it is: sloppy intellectual work, a standard not permitted to women in academia. RITA ADDESSA Philadelphia, Aug. 25, 1998

key_6.snippet: Watching a male sweat bee mate with a female sweat bee, Penelope Kukuk, a Cornell University entomologist noticed that once they had mated the female seemed to lose her appeal to male bees, including the one with which she had just mated. The rese...
key_6.lead_paragraph: Watching a male sweat bee mate with a female sweat bee, Penelope Kukuk, a Cornell University entomologist noticed that once they had mated the female seemed to lose her appeal to male bees, including the one with which she had just mated. The researcher wondered why. She knew it had been suspected that male sweat bees could recognize and ''remember'' the odors of their female mates, and thereby avoid them. But she also realized that the males would have had to learn an incredible number of odors to perform such behavior, a feat of memory that was beyond insects that were no bigger than small houseflies.

key_6.snippet: It is said that clothes make the man, but for the status-seeking cockroach male, what really matters is how he smells.    Researchers reported in the current issue of the journal Nature that the difference between the top cockroach and those squir...
key_6.lead_paragraph: It is said that clothes make the man, but for the status-seeking cockroach male, what really matters is how he smells. Researchers reported in the current issue of the journal Nature that the difference between the top cockroach and those squirming at the bottom of a social heap of males is the exact blend of three scents in each male's status-defining aroma. This may be the first time odor has been pegged as a badge of status.

key_7.lead_paragraph: TO THE HOME SECTION: Though I cannot presume to understand K.C. Cole's situation of being a middle-aged woman involved in the male-dominated discipline of physics (''Hers,'' Dec. 3), I can soundly disagree with her insights as they are applied to my generation. Regarding her daughter's inability to cope with freshman calculus at Harvard, instead of blaming her daughter's failures on, perhaps, her very normal difficulties in adjusting to a new school, Miss Cole portrays her daughter as a victim of a male-dominated academic society.

key_7.snippet: SCIENTISTS have long wondered why various species of animal, including human beings, sometimes produce lopsided ratios of male to female offspring. For example, in two species of seal it has been found that females giving birth early in the season...
key_7.lead_paragraph: SCIENTISTS have long wondered why various species of animal, including human beings, sometimes produce lopsided ratios of male to female offspring. For example, in two species of seal it has been found that females giving birth early in the season produce 12 males for every 10 females. Those who pup late produce a male-to-female ratio of 8 to 10, evening the score. Human mothers under stress tend to produce fewer boys than girls.

headline.main: SPECIES SURVIVAL LINKED TO LOPSIDED SEX RATIOS

key_8.snippet: The barriers that keep minorities from enjoying full access to the technological revolution have been widely commented on. Less talked about is another ''digital divide,'' the fact that fewer women are entering today's booming technology fields.  ...
key_8.lead_paragraph: The barriers that keep minorities from enjoying full access to the technological revolution have been widely commented on. Less talked about is another ''digital divide,'' the fact that fewer women are entering today's booming technology fields. Studies show that women are active users of the new technology and that female Internet users slightly outnumber male users. But the paucity of women creating that technology is cause for concern. The most recent National Science Foundation statistics show that between 1984 and 1997, the proportion of women receiving bachelor's degrees in computer science dropped from 37 percent to 27 percent. Currently, women make up only 20 percent of the information technology work force.
key_8.abstract: Editorial laments fact that fewer women are entering booming technology fields; says technology industry badly needs more workers and that women represent major untapped source of talent that could solve shortage (S)

headline.main: Technology's Gender Gap

key_8.snippet: Female praying mantises and black widow spiders eat their lovers during or after sex. Female angler fish keep their mates captive as tiny parasites attached to their bodies, the male diminished in size to little more than a reproductive organ.    ...
key_8.lead_paragraph: Female praying mantises and black widow spiders eat their lovers during or after sex. Female angler fish keep their mates captive as tiny parasites attached to their bodies, the male diminished in size to little more than a reproductive organ. Now the annals of kinky sex in the animal kingdom are getting wilder with revelations about the giant squid, the world's largest known invertebrate, a colossus of the deep up to 70 feet long that is the most famous of legendary sea monsters. The male, it turns out, is a savage lover, clutching the female in the darkness and injecting sperm into her skin at high pressure, creating a small wound.

headline.main: October 19-25; Birds Do It. So Do Squid, But Violently.

key_8.snippet: Male frogs exposed to very low doses of a common weed killer can develop multiple sex organs, sometimes both male and female, researchers in California have discovered.    The weed killer, atrazine, is the most commonly used one in North America a...
key_8.lead_paragraph: Male frogs exposed to very low doses of a common weed killer can develop multiple sex organs, sometimes both male and female, researchers in California have discovered. The weed killer, atrazine, is the most commonly used one in North America and can be found in rainwater, snow runoff and ground water, said Tyrone B. Hayes of the University of California, who led the research. ''There is virtually no atrazine-free environment,'' Dr. Hayes said.
key_8.abstract: Study led by Dr Tyrone B Hayes finds that male frogs exposed to very low doses of common weed killer atrazine can develop multiple sex organs, sometimes both male and female; research is reported in Proceedings of the National Academy of Science (S)

headline.main: Weed Killer Deforms Frogs In Sex Organs, Study Finds

key_8.snippet: Field experiments in Louisiana swamps have shown that when the eggs of alligators are incubated at temperatures below 86 degrees Fahrenheit, all the eggs produce females. If the temperature is above 93 degrees, only males are hatched. The effect r...
key_8.lead_paragraph: Field experiments in Louisiana swamps have shown that when the eggs of alligators are incubated at temperatures below 86 degrees Fahrenheit, all the eggs produce females. If the temperature is above 93 degrees, only males are hatched. The effect runs exactly opposite to earlier observations on turtles, where higher incubation temperatures produce females.

key_9.lead_paragraph: As long as the male wrasse, a family of fish inhabiting Australia's Great Barrier Reef, stays alive, he dominates his harem of three to six females, keeping each in her place in the well-ordered hierarchy below him.
key_9.abstract: Dr D R Robertson of Queensland Univ (Brisbane, Australia) reveals findings made in study on wrasse fish, which inhabits Australia s Great Barrier Reef, current issue of Science magazine; repts that male wrasse, which dominates harem consisting of 3 to 6 females and keeps each in her place in well-ordered hierarchy below him, is replaced by top harem member when he dies; female wrasse, because of absence of male dominance, goes through natural sex change and acquires males' aggressive behavioral patterns within hrs following male's death; some 14 to 18 days later female ovaries are transformed into testes; Dr Robertson observed species of wrasse known as labroides dimidiatus

key_9.snippet: To the Editor:     Re your conversation with Prof. Ben A. Barres (''Dismissing 'Sexist Opinions' About Women's Place in Science,'' July 18): Dr. Barres's experience as both a female scientist and a male scientist betrays the lie perpetuated by hig...
key_9.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re your conversation with Prof. Ben A. Barres (''Dismissing 'Sexist Opinions' About Women's Place in Science,'' July 18): Dr. Barres's experience as both a female scientist and a male scientist betrays the lie perpetuated by high-profile academic figures, like Lawrence H. Summers, the former Harvard president, who denigrate the skill and intelligence of women. I can only hope that this interview with Professor Barres, with his pitch-perfect accuracy about the state of gender relations in this country, will reach the hearts and minds it desperately needs to. I am not holding my breath. Maureen Sullivan Cambridge, Mass. The writer is a visiting assistant professor of social studies at Harvard. To the Editor: I find it amazing that Ben A. Barres, as both a transgender person and a neurobiologist, would not recognize innate differences in the structure and functioning of male and female brains. Difference does not mean deficiency. Women can do science; they just do it differently. Judy B. Rosener Irvine, Calif. The writer is an emerita professor of business at the University of California, Irvine.
key_9.abstract: Maureen Sullivan letter on July 18 interview with transgender scientist Prof Ben A Barres agrees that more needs to be done to support women scientists; Judy B Rosener letter suggests that men and women do have different brain structure, but holds that does not make one gender deficient in understanding science; photo (M)

headline.main: Sexism in Science

key_9.snippet: To the Editor:    The 1996 Nobel prizes have all been announced and, as usual, not one woman has received an award in science. Since the award was established in 1901, more than 300 men and only 9 women have been honored in science....
key_9.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The 1996 Nobel prizes have all been announced and, as usual, not one woman has received an award in science. Since the award was established in 1901, more than 300 men and only 9 women have been honored in science.
key_9.abstract: Christopher D Bodkin letter notes only 9 nine women, compared with more than 300 men, have received Nobel Prizes in science since award was established in 1901 (S)

headline.main: Science and Women
headline.kicker: For Clinton and Dole, A Nobel-Level Query

key_9.snippet: To the Editor:   "The Male of the Species: Why Is He Needed?" (Science Times, May 17) asks this relevant question from the standpoint of the female of the species. The underlying assumption is that the male and the female of each species compete f...
key_9.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: "The Male of the Species: Why Is He Needed?" (Science Times, May 17) asks this relevant question from the standpoint of the female of the species. The underlying assumption is that the male and the female of each species compete for power, much as they do in modern-day human society.
